abstract: What’s the best way to set up iTunes to support two iPods on a shared computer?
snippet: What’s the best way to set up iTunes to support two iPods on a shared computer?
lead_paragraph: Q. My husband and I each own an iPod and we share a computer at home. We’d like to share some music, but we also want to create our own playlists. What’s the best way to set up iTunes to support two iPods on a shared computer?

abstract: Many cameras will let you disable the logo screen and jump right into the live viewfinder, which saves start-up time.
snippet: Many cameras will let you disable the logo screen and jump right into the live viewfinder, which saves start-up time.
lead_paragraph: Have you missed too many spur-of-the-moment shots with the digital camera because you had to wait for the company’s splash screen to go away when you turned the camera on? Many cameras will let you disable the logo screen and jump right into the live viewfinder, which saves start-up time. Just go to the camera’s menu or settings area and look for a “start-up screen” or similar option, then choose not to use it; check your camera’s manual for specific instructions. Within the camera’s menus, you should also be able to adjust the length of the review time each photo stays on the LCD screen after you snap it. By decreasing the time the last image stays on screen, you can get back to shooting photos more quickly. J. D. BIERSDORFER

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Disabling Your Camera’s Start-Up Screen

abstract: The corporate operating system of Apple so revolves around the autocratic vision of Steve Jobs that it will need a cultural upgrade if he doesn’t return from medical leave.
snippet: The corporate operating system of Apple so revolves around the autocratic vision of Steve Jobs that it will need a cultural upgrade if he doesn’t return from medical leave.
lead_paragraph: We don’t know what’s wrong with Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive. But it’s got to be serious. You don’t take a six-month leave of absence, as he is, just because you’ve got a stomachache.

headline.main: What If Steve Jobs Doesn’t Come Back to Work?

abstract: Casting a pall over one of the world’s most closely watched companies, Steven P. Jobs, chief executive of Apple, said on Wednesday that he was taking a leave of absence because of health concerns, The New York Times’s Brad Stone reported.
lead_paragraph: Casting a pall over one of the world’s most closely watched companies, Steven P. Jobs, chief executive of Apple, said on Wednesday that he was taking a leave of absence because of health concerns, The New York Times’s Brad Stone reported.

abstract: Trying to parse the changing story line about the most important person at one of the most high-profile companies in America.
snippet: Trying to parse the changing story line about the most important person at one of the most high-profile companies in America.
lead_paragraph: Last week, when Steve Jobs announced that his recent weight loss was due to “a hormone imbalance,” I got calls from reporters and others (which, I must admit, I ducked) asking me if that was the medical problem he had confessed to when he and I had had our infamous phone call last summer — the one where he called me a slime bucket and denied that he had a recurrence of cancer. The answer is no, it wasn’t. It was something else — which of course I still can’t disclose because the conversation was off the record.

headline.main: It’s Time for Apple to Come Clean
